name: all/@jali-ms/util/src/argument-empty-string-error.js
ArgumentEmptyStringError
description:
Represents that an argument erroneously has an empty string value.

Throw this {@link Error} if a parameter must be a non-empty string.
examples:
<caption>The argument for the parameter lastName is an empty string.</caption>
throw new ArgumentEmptyStringError('lastName');

name: constructor
description: Initializes a new instance of the {@link ArgumentEmptyStringError} class.

params.name: name
params.description: The parameter name. Default is no name.

params.name: message
params.description:
Specified message. Otherwise, a generic message will be used like *Argument must not be an
   empty string. Yours is empty*.

name: all/@jali-ms/util/src/argument-error.js
ArgumentError
description:
Represents that an argument has violated a requirement.

Throw this {@link Error} if a parameter has violated a requirement that can't be represented by
a more specific argument error.

> **Note:** {@link ArgumentError} is the base class for all the Jali argument errors.

> **Note:** The default message in all Jali argument error classes begin with
> **Error in argument** if `name` is not specified; otherwise **Error in argument '**
> *argument-name* **'** is used. If `message` is specified,  a colon is prefixed. All Jali
> subclasses specify a message.
examples:
<caption>The argument for the parameter pairs has an odd number of elements.</caption>
throw new ArgumentError('pairs', `Argument must have an even number of elements. Yours has ` +
  `'${pairs.length}'`);

name: constructor
description: Initializes a new instance of the {@link ArgumentError} class.

params.name: name
params.description: The parameter name. Default is no name.

params.name: message
params.description: An optional message. Default is no message. See class documentation for more details.*.

name: all/@jali-ms/util/src/argument-false-error.js
ArgumentFalseError
description:
Represents that an argument erroneously has a value of `false`.

Throw this {@link Error} if a parameter must be `true`.
examples:
<caption>The argument for the parameter isValid is `false`.</caption>
throw new ArgumentFalseError('lastName');

name: constructor
description: Initializes a new instance of the {@link ArgumentFalseError} class.

params.name: name
params.description: The parameter name. Default is no name.

params.name: message
params.description:
Specified message. Otherwise, a generic message will be used like *Argument must have a
   truthy value. Yours is 'false'*.

name: all/@jali-ms/util/src/argument-falsy-error.js
content: import { default as ArgumentError } from './argument-error'; /** * Represents that an argument erroneously has a _falsy_ value. * * Throw this {@link Error} if a parameter must be _truthy_ and can't be represented by a more * specific argument error. * * @example The argument for the parameter item is falsy. * throw new ArgumentFalsyError('item'); * * @see * package @jali-ms/util * @see * module @jali-ms/util/errors * @see * Definition of falsy (MDN) * @see {@link verifyDefined} * @see {@link verifyTruthy} * @public * @since 0.0.1 */ export default class ArgumentFalsyError extends ArgumentError { /** * Initializes a new instance of the {@link ArgumentFalsyError} class. * * @param {string} [name] - * The parameter name. Default is no name. * @param {string} [message] - * Specified message. Otherwise, a generic message will be used like *Argument must have a * truthy value. Yours does not*. * @public * @since 0.0.1 */ constructor(name, message) { super(name, Class.makeFalsyTypedMessage(message)); } /** * Builds a default error message for subclasses. * @param {string}: [message] - * Specified message. Otherwise, a generic message will be created like *Argument must have a * truthy value. Yours ${type ? `is '${type}'` : 'does not'*. * @param {string}: [type] - * value to display in the message. Default is to display no value. * @protected * @since 0.0.1 */ static makeFalsyTypedMessage(message, type) { return message || `Argument must have a truthy value. Yours ${type ? `is '${type}'` : 'does not'}`; } } const Class = ArgumentFalsyError; // tslint:disable-line:variable-name no-use-before-declare

name: ArgumentFalsyError
description:
Represents that an argument erroneously has a _falsy_ value.

Throw this {@link Error} if a parameter must be _truthy_ and can't be represented by a more
specific argument error.
examples:
<caption>The argument for the parameter item is falsy.</caption>
throw new ArgumentFalsyError('item');

name: constructor
description: Initializes a new instance of the {@link ArgumentFalsyError} class.

params.name: name
params.description: The parameter name. Default is no name.

params.name: message
params.description:
Specified message. Otherwise, a generic message will be used like *Argument must have a
   truthy value. Yours does not*.

name: makeFalsyTypedMessage
description: Builds a default error message for subclasses.

params.name: {string}:
params.description:
[message] -
   Specified message. Otherwise, a generic message will be created like *Argument must have a
   truthy value. Yours ${type ? `is '${type}'` : 'does not'*.

params.name: {string}:
params.description:
[type] -
   value to display in the message. Default is to display no value.

name: all/@jali-ms/util/src/argument-nan-error.js
ArgumentNanError
description:
Represents that an argument erroneously has a value of `NaN`.

Throw this {@link Error} if a parameter must be a `number`.
examples:
<caption>The argument for the parameter price is `NaN`.</caption>
throw new ArgumentNanError('price');

name: constructor
description: Initializes a new instance of the {@link ArgumentNanError} class.

params.name: name
params.description: The parameter name. Default is no name.

params.name: message
params.description:
Specified message. Otherwise, a generic message will be used like *Argument must have a
   truthy value. Yours is 'NaN'*.

name: all/@jali-ms/util/src/argument-null-error.js
ArgumentNullError
description:
Represents that an argument erroneously has a value of `null`.

Throw this {@link Error} if a parameter must be an object.
examples:
<caption>The argument for the parameter entity is `null`.</caption>
throw new ArgumentNullError('entity');

name: constructor
description: Initializes a new instance of the {@link ArgumentNullError} class.

params.name: name
params.description: The parameter name. Default is no name.

params.name: message
params.description:
Specified message. Otherwise, a generic message will be used like *Argument must have a
    non-null value. Yours is 'null'*.

name: all/@jali-ms/util/src/argument-type-error.js
content: import { default as ArgumentError } from './argument-error'; /** * Represents that an argument has an invalid type or an object with the incorrect structure. * * Throw this {@link Error} if a parameter has an invalid type and can't be represented by a more * specific argument error. * * @example The argument for the parameter motor is missing a property. * throw new ArgumentTypeError( * 'motor', `The argument is not a valid 'Motor'. It lacks the 'start' method`); * * @see * package @jali-ms/util * @see * module @jali-ms/util/errors * @see {@link verifyDefined} * @see {@link verifyTruthy} * @public * @since 0.0.1 */ export default class ArgumentTypeError extends ArgumentError { /** * Initializes a new instance of the {@link ArgumentTypeError} class. * * @param {!string} type - * The expected parameter type. * @param {string} [name] - * The parameter name. Default is no name. * @param {string} [message] - * Specified message. Otherwise, a generic message will be used like *Argument must have type * '${type}'. Yours is not*. * @public * @since 0.0.1 */ constructor(type, name, message) { super(name, Class.makeTypeMessage(type, message)); } /** * Builds a default error message for subclasses. * @param {!string}: type - * The expected parameter type. * @param {string}: [message] - * Specified message. Otherwise, a generic message will be created like *Argument must have * type '${type}'. Yours is not*. * @protected * @since 0.0.1 */ static makeTypeMessage(type, message) { return message || `Argument must have type '${type}'. Yours is not`; } } const Class = ArgumentTypeError; // tslint:disable-line:variable-name no-use-before-declare

name: ArgumentTypeError
description:
Represents that an argument has an invalid type or an object with the incorrect structure.

Throw this {@link Error} if a parameter has an invalid type and can't be represented by a more
specific argument error.
examples:
<caption>The argument for the parameter motor is missing a property.</caption>
throw new ArgumentTypeError(
   'motor', `The argument is not a valid 'Motor'. It lacks the 'start' method`);

name: constructor
description: Initializes a new instance of the {@link ArgumentTypeError} class.

params.name: type
params.description: The expected parameter type.

params.name: name
params.description: The parameter name. Default is no name.

params.name: message
params.description:
Specified message. Otherwise, a generic message will be used like *Argument must have type
   '${type}'. Yours is not*.

name: makeTypeMessage
description: Builds a default error message for subclasses.

params.name: {!string}:
params.description:
type -
   The expected parameter type.

params.name: {string}:
params.description:
[message] -
   Specified message. Otherwise, a generic message will be created like *Argument must have
   type '${type}'. Yours is not*.

name: all/@jali-ms/util/src/argument-undefined-error.js
ArgumentUndefinedError
description:
Represents that an argument erroneously is 'undefined'.

Throw this {@link Error} if a parameter must have a value.
examples:
<caption>The argument for the parameter element is undefined.</caption>
throw new ArgumentUndefinedError('element');

name: constructor
description: Initializes a new instance of the {@link ArgumentUndefinedError} class.

params.name: name
params.description: The parameter name. Default is no name.

params.name: message
params.description:
Specified message. Otherwise, a generic message will be used like *Argument must be
   defined. Yours is 'undefined*.

name: all/@jali-ms/util/src/argument-verifiers.js
verifyArgument
description: Throws an error if the specified argument value does not pass the specified test.
examples:
<caption>verify that parameter deposit is non-negative</caption>
verifyArgument('deposit', deposit, arg => arg > 0.0);

params.name: T
params.description:
The `value` type. **Note:** This is a TypeScript type parameter, not a parameter of the
   function.

params.name: name
params.description: The formal parameter name.

params.name: value
params.description: The function argument.

params.name: test
params.description: Evaluates whether the value meets expectations.

params.name: message
params.description: Optional custom message or message factory.

name: verifyArray
description:
Throws an error if the specified argument is not an `Array`.

> **Note:** Calls {@link Array.isArray}.
examples:
<caption>verify that parameter collection is an Array</caption>
verifyArray('collection', collection);

params.name: T
params.description:
The `element` type. **Note:** This is a TypeScript type parameter, not a parameter of the
   function.

params.name: name
params.description: The formal parameter name.

params.name: value
params.description: The function argument.

params.name: message
params.description: Optional custom message or message factory.

name: verifyBoolean
description:
Throws an error if the specified argument is not strictly a boolean value.

> **Note:** If you want to test for _truthy_ values, use {@link verifyTruthy}.
examples:
<caption>verify that parameter isValid is boolean</caption>
verifyBoolean('isValid', isValid);

params.name: name
params.description: The formal parameter name.

params.name: value
params.description: The function argument.

params.name: message
params.description: Optional custom message or message factory.

name: verifyDefined
description:
Throws an error if the specified argument is `undefined`.

> **Note:** If you want to test for _truthy_ values, use {@link verifyTruthy}.
examples:
<caption>verify that parameter element is defined</caption>
verifyDefined('element', element);

params.name: T
params.description:
The `value` type. **Note:** This is a TypeScript type parameter, not a parameter of the
   function.

params.name: name
params.description: The formal parameter name.

params.name: value
params.description: The function argument.

params.name: message
params.description: Optional custom message or message factory.

name: verifyFunction
description:
Throws an error if the specified argument is not strictly a function expression.

> **Note:** If you want to test for _truthy_ values, use {@link verifyTruthy}.
examples:
<caption>verify that parameter factory is a function</caption>
verifyFunction('factory', factory);

params.name: name
params.description: The formal parameter name.

params.name: value
params.description: The function argument.

params.name: message
params.description: Optional custom message or message factory.

name: verifyIterable
description:
Throws an error if the specified argument does not support iteration.

> **Note:** Calls {@link isIterable} to determine iterability.
examples:
<caption>verify that parameter collection is iterable</caption>
verifyIterable('collection', collection);

params.name: T
params.description:
The `element` type. **Note:** This is a TypeScript type parameter, not a parameter of the
   function.

params.name: name
params.description: The formal parameter name.

params.name: value
params.description: The function argument.

params.name: message
params.description: Optional custom message or message factory.

throws.description: The argument does not support iteration.

name: verifyNonEmpty
description: Throws an error if the specified argument value is not a non-empty string.
examples:
<caption>verify that parameter firstName is a non-empty string</caption>
verifyNonEmpty('firstName', firstName);

params.name: name
params.description: the formal parameter name

params.name: value
params.description: the function argument

params.name: message
params.description: optional custom message or message factory

name: verifyNonZero
description: Throws an error if the specified argument value is not a non-zero number.
examples:
<caption>verify that parameter height has a nonzero value</caption>
verifyNonEmpty('height', height);

params.name: name
params.description: the formal parameter name

params.name: value
params.description: the function argument

params.name: message
params.description: optional custom message or message factory

throws.description: the argument is a number the value zero.

name: verifyNotNull
description:
Throws an error if the specified argument value is `undefined` or `null`.

> **Note:** Consider using {@link verifyTruthy} or {@link verifyObject}.
examples:
<caption>verify that parameter height has a nonzero value</caption>
verifyNonEmpty('height', height);

params.name: name
params.description: the formal parameter name

params.name: value
params.description: the function argument

params.name: message
params.description: optional custom message or message factory

throws.description: the argument is a number the value zero.

name: verifyNotWhitespace
description: Throws an error if the specified argument is not a string with non whitespace characters.
examples:
<caption>verify that parameter firstName has non-whitespace characters</caption>
verifyNotWhitespace('firstName', firstName);

params.name: name
params.description: the formal parameter name

params.name: value
params.description: the function argument

params.name: message
params.description: optional custom message or message factory

throws.description: the argument has only whitespace characters.

name: verifyNumber
description: Throws an error if the specified argument value is not a `number` or has a value of `NaN`.
examples:
<caption>verify that parameter price is a number</caption>
verifyNumber('price', price);

params.name: name
params.description: the formal parameter name

params.name: value
params.description: the function argument

params.name: message
params.description: optional custom message or message factory

throws.description: the argument is a number the value zero.

name: verifyObject
description:
Throws an error if the specified argument value is not an `Object`.

> **Note:** To exclude `null` values also call {@link verifyNotNull}
examples:
<caption>verify that parameter height has a nonzero value</caption>
verifyNonEmpty('height', height);

params.name: name
params.description: the formal parameter name

params.name: value
params.description: the function argument

params.name: message
params.description: optional custom message or message factory

name: verifyString
description:
Throws an error if the specified argument value is not a `string`.

> **Note:** To verify a meaningful value consider using {@link verifyNonEmpty} or
> {@link verifyNotWhitespace}.
examples:
<caption>verify that parameter alphabet is a string</caption>
verifyNonEmpty('alphabet', alphabet);

params.name: name
params.description: the formal parameter name

params.name: value
params.description: the function argument

params.name: message
params.description: optional custom message or message factory

name: verifyTrue
description:
Throws an error if the specified argument value is not a boolean with the value 'true'.

> **Note:** To verify a _truthy_ value, use {@link verifyTruthy}.
examples:
<caption>verify that parameter isValid is true</caption>
verifyNonEmpty('isValid', isValid);

params.name: name
params.description: the formal parameter name

params.name: value
params.description: the function argument

params.name: message
params.description: optional custom message or message factory

throws.description: the argument is a number the value zero.

name: verifyTruthy
description:
Throws an error if the specified argument value is not _truthy_.

The `loose` parameter changes what exception is thrown. If `loose`, then only
{@link ArgumentFalsyError} is thrown. Otherwise, the exception for the appropriate _falsy_ value
is thrown.

> **Note:** You can test for any of the _falsy_ values individually using the appropriate
> `verify...` function.
examples:
<caption>verify that parameter item is truthy</caption>
verifyTruthy('item', item);

params.name: T
params.description:
The `value` type. **Note:** This is a TypeScript type parameter, not a parameter of the
   function.

params.name: name
params.description: the formal parameter name

params.name: value
params.description: the function argument

params.name: message
params.description: optional custom message or message factory

throws.description: the argument is _falsy_ and `loose` is specified.
the argument is an empty `string` and `loose` is not specified.
the argument has the value `false` and `loose` is not specified.
the argument has the value `NaN` and `loose` is not specified.
the argument has the value `null` and `loose` is not specified.
the argument is `undefined` and `loose` is not specified.
the argument is zero and `loose` is not specified.

name: all/@jali-ms/util/src/argument-whitespace-string-error.js
ArgumentWhitespaceStringError
description:
Represents that a string argument erroneously has only whitespace characters.

Throw this {@link Error} if a parameter must have non-whitespace content.
examples:
<caption>The string argument for the parameter firstName has only whitespace.</caption>
throw new ArgumentWhitespaceStringError('firstName');

name: constructor
description: Initializes a new instance of the {@link ArgumentEmptyStringError} class.

params.name: name
params.description: The parameter name. Default is no name.

params.name: message
params.description:
Specified message. Otherwise, a generic message will be used like *Argument must contain
   non-whitespace characters. Yours has only whitespace*.

name: all/@jali-ms/util/src/argument-zero-error.js
ArgumentZeroError
description:
Represents that an argument erroneously has a value of zero.

Throw this {@link Error} if a parameter must have a non-zero value.
examples:
<caption>The argument for the parameter height is zero.</caption>
throw new ArgumentZeroError('height');

name: constructor
description: Initializes a new instance of the {@link ArgumentZeroError} class.

params.name: name
params.description: The parameter name. Default is no name.

params.name: message
params.description:
Specified message. Otherwise, a generic message will be used like *Argument must have a
   truthy value. Yours is 'zero'*.

all/@jali-ms/util/src/iterables.js

params.name: T
params.description:
The `Iterator` element type. NOTE: This is a TypeScript type parameter, not a parameter of the
   function.

params.name: element
params.description: The iteration element

params.name: index
params.description: The index of the element

params.name: sequence
params.description: The sequence being iterated

return.description: A value indicating whether the specified element passed the test.

params.name: T
params.description:
The input `Iterator` element type. NOTE: This is a TypeScript type parameter, not a parameter
   of the function.

params.name: U
params.description:
The output `Iterator` element type. NOTE: This is a TypeScript type parameter, not a parameter

params.name: element
params.description: The iteration element

params.name: index
params.description: The index of the element

params.name: sequence
params.description: The sequence being iterated

params.name: T
params.description:
The input `Iterator` element type. NOTE: This is a TypeScript type parameter, not a parameter
   of the function.

params.name: U
params.description:
The output `Iterator` element type. NOTE: This is a TypeScript type parameter, not a parameter
   of the function.

params.name: previousValue
params.description:
For the first execution either an `initialValue`, if specified, or the first element in the
   sequence. Otherwise, an intermediary accumulated value.

params.name: currentValue
params.description: The iteration element.

params.name: index
params.description: The index of the iteration element

params.name: sequence
params.description: The sequence being iterated

name: asArray
description: Converts an argument that could either be a value of a type or a sequence of that type to an array of that type. Specify the constructor to specify the iteration type. Use for values, such as strings, that are also iterables of another type. > **Note:** To treat a string as a value rather than a sequence of characters, you must specify > the `String` constructor. > **Note:** To only ensure an iterable value, use {@link asIterable}. > **Note:** {@link asArray} is different from > target="_blank">Array.from or the > target="_blank">spread operator, which only convert an iterable to an array. > {@link asArray} ensures a value that can be a scalar value or an array of values is converted > to an array.
examples:
<caption>ensures argument personOrPersons is converted to an array</caption>
const persons = Iterables.asArray(personOrPersons);

<caption>ensures string argument colorOrColors is converted to an array</caption>
const persons = Iterables.asArray(colorOrColors, String);

params.name: T
params.description:
The `value` type. **Note:** This is a TypeScript type parameter, not a parameter of the
   function.

params.name: valueOrSequence
params.description: A value that could be a value or an Iterable of that value type.

params.name: ctor
params.description: Optional constructor for the type being iterated.

return.description: an array of the value type.

name: asIterable
description:
Converts an argument that could either be a value of a type or a sequence of that type to
a sequence of that type.

Specify the constructor to specify the iteration type. Use for values, such as strings, that are
also iterables of another type.

> **Note:** To treat a string as a value rather than a sequence of characters, you must specify
> the `String` constructor.

> **Note:** To ensure an Array value, use {@link toArray}.
examples:
<caption>ensures argument idOrIds is converted to an iterable</caption>
const ids = Iterables.asIterable(idOrIds);

params.name: T
params.description:
The `value` type. **Note:** This is a TypeScript type parameter, not a parameter of the
   function.

params.name: valueOrSequence
params.description: A value that could be a value or an Iterable of that value type.

params.name: ctor
params.description: Optional constructor for the type being iterated.

name: concat
description: Concatenates a sequence of a type with zero or more other sequences of that type.

params.name: T
params.description:
The `Iterator` element type. NOTE: This is a TypeScript type parameter, not a parameter of the
   function.

params.name: sequence
params.description: The `Iterable` to operate on

params.name: items
params.description: Array of `Iterable` to concatenate.

name: every
description: Returns a value indicating whether every element fulfills the specified test.

params.name: T
params.description:
The `Iterator` element type. NOTE: This is a TypeScript type parameter, not a parameter of the
   function.

params.name: sequence
params.description: The `Iterable` to operate on

params.name: test
params.description:
A function that returns a value indicating whether an element of the sequence fulfills the
   requirement.

name: filter
description:
Returns a subset of the sequence of those elements that pass the specified test.

> **Note:** To return whether a match was found, use {@link includes}. To return the first
> matching value, use {@link find}.

params.name: T
params.description:
The `Iterator` element type. NOTE: This is a TypeScript type parameter, not a parameter of the
   function.

params.name: sequence
params.description: The `Iterable` to operate on

params.name: test
params.description: The filter function

name: find
description:
Returns the first value matching the specified test or `undefined` if no match was found. If no
test is specified, returns the first element, or `undefined` if the sequence is empty.

> **Note:** To return whether a match was found, use {@link some}. To match a specific element
> value, use {@link includes}. To return all matching values, use {@link filter}.

params.name: T
params.description:
The `Iterator` element type. NOTE: This is a TypeScript type parameter, not a parameter of the
   function.

params.name: sequence
params.description: The `Iterable` to operate on

params.name: test
params.description:
A function that returns a value indicating whether an element of the sequence fulfills the
   requirement.

return.description: The matched element or `undefined` if no match is found.

name: includes
description:
Returns a value indicating whether a match for the specified test was found.

> **Note:** To return the first matching value, use {@link find}. To return all matching values
> use {@link filter}.

params.name: T
params.description:
The `Iterator` element type. NOTE: This is a TypeScript type parameter, not a parameter of the
   function.

params.name: sequence
params.description: The `Iterable` to operate on

params.name: value
params.description: The value search for strictly.

return.description: `true` if the element was found; otherwise, `false`.

name: map
description:
Returns a sequence of elements that are the result of calling the specified converter function on
each element.

params.name: T
params.description:
The `Iterator` element type. NOTE: This is a TypeScript type parameter, not a parameter of the
   function.

params.name: U
params.description:
The result type of the converter function. NOTE: This is a TypeScript type parameter, not a
   parameter of the function.

params.name: sequence
params.description: The `Iterable` to operate on

params.name: converter
params.description: The element conversion function.

name: reduce
description:
Aggregates a sequence to a single computed element value.

If `initialValue` is specified `accumulator` is called for the first element using the initial
value. Otherwise, it is called against the second element using the first element as the initial
value.

params.name: T
params.description:
The `Iterator` element type. NOTE: This is a TypeScript type parameter, not a parameter of the
   function.

params.name: U
params.description:
The accumulator result type. NOTE: This is a TypeScript type parameter, not a parameter of the
   function.

params.name: sequence
params.description: The `Iterable` to operate on

params.name: accumulator
params.description: The element aggregation function

params.name: initialValue
params.description: Optional initial value; otherwise, first element is used as initial value

name: slice
description: Returns a segment of the original sequence. Skips `begin` elements and takes `end - begin` elements or the rest of the elements if `end` is not specified. If begin is past the last element, no elements are returned. If `begin` or `end` is a negative value, the sequence is converted to an array and Array#slice is called. > **Note:** To retrieve the first element, use {@link first} or {@link firstOrDefault}.

params.name: T
params.description:
The `Iterator` element type. NOTE: This is a TypeScript type parameter, not a parameter of the
   function.

params.name: sequence
params.description: The `Iterable` to operate on

params.name: begin
params.description: The first element to include. If negative, converts to an array and uses Array#slice

params.name: end
params.description: The first element to include.

name: some
description:
Returns a value indicating whether any of the elements of a sequence pass the specified test.

> **Note:** To return the first matching value, use {@link find}. To return all matching values,
> use {@link filter}. To match on equality, use {@link includes}.

params.name: T
params.description: The `Iterator` element type. NOTE: This is a TypeScript type parameter, not a parameter of the function.

params.name: sequence
params.description: The `Iterable` to operate on

params.name: test
params.description:
If not defined, indicates that the function should test for any existing elements; otherwise,
   a function that indicates whether an element meets a requirement.

return.description: `true` if an element was found that meets the test; otherwise, `false`;

name: toMap
description: Converts a sequence to a {@link Map} using the specified key selector function.

params.name: TKey
params.description:
The key type for the {@link Map}. NOTE: This is a TypeScript type parameter, not a parameter
   of the function.

params.name: TValue
params.description:
The `Iterable` element type and the value type for the {@link Map}. NOTE: This is a TypeScript
   type parameter, not a parameter of the function.

params.name: sequence
params.description: The `Iterable` to operate on

params.name: keySelector
params.description: The function that retrieves a key for the specified element.

name: all/@jali-ms/util/src/type-guards.js
all/@jali-ms/util/type-guards/index.js
content: export * from '../src/type-guards';
